The sutra says: The World-Honored One said, Having few desires is the most peaceful and blissful. Contentment is the greatest wealth and honor.
Upholding the precepts is always dignified.
Violating the precepts is always ugly. The commentary says: This is the answer.
It is the sequential answer to the previous question, Having few desires is the most peaceful and blissful.
It answers the first question.
Frugality is having few.
Addiction is called desire.
In the world, addiction is only a little and only extensive. The foolish mind quickly breaks down.
Soon, there is longing.
The suffering and distress cut the heart.
The Buddha's teachings are contrary to worldly customs, valuing non-action.
Having few desires and few requests is the most peaceful and blissful.
Moreover, the sutra says:
One who has few desires is without flattery.
Seeking the intentions of others.
Having few desires is still something to be cultivated.
How much more so for being able to give rise to various merits and virtues.
One who has few desires has nirvana.
The bliss of nirvana is the most blissful among all kinds of bliss.
Thus, the cause of the greatest happiness is obtained through few desires.
The effect is indicated by the cause.
Therefore, it is said that few desires are the greatest happiness.
Contentment is great wealth and nobility answers the second question.
Although worldly fools may obtain wealth and nobility, their greed increases and they are always discontented.
A contented person has nothing to do and nothing to worry about.
There is nothing to take away.
He always has a surplus.
Therefore, he is greatly wealthy and noble.
The sutra says:
A contented person
Even if sleeping on the ground, is still at ease.

Is still dissatisfied.
This is like the story of King MÅ«rdhaja.
It also says:ğŸ”½An uncontented person is poor even if wealthy.
A contented person is wealthy even if poor.
Therefore, it is said that contentment is great wealth and nobility.
Upholding precepts is always dignified answers the third question.
A person who upholds the precepts has pure morality.
They will soon obtain the delightful and wondrous characteristics of humans and gods.
In the distant future, one attains the dignified Dharma body of the Three Vehicles.
Therefore, it is said that upholding precepts is always dignified.
Like King Udayana's wife with the marks who upheld the precepts for one day.
That night, she passed away and was reborn in the heavens, attaining an upright body.
Relying on the king's previous agreement,
she returned to inform the king.
Disdaining the king's foul body, she returned to the heavens.
This is the very matter.
Breaking precepts is always ugly answers the fourth question.
For one who breaks precepts, sinful karma increases,
falling into the three evil paths.
Receiving an ugly body.
If reborn as a human,
the faculties are incomplete.
In borderlands and low-caste families, the appearance is crude and people do not enjoy seeing it.
For hundreds of thousands of lifetimes.
Therefore, it is said that breaking precepts is always ugly.

There are also four questions.

Who are the good relatives? This is the first question.

or a child who is not filial,ğŸ”½or a brother who is not obedient,

like water and milk mixed together,

What is an evil-hearted enemy? This is the second question.
Malice towards the virtuous and jealousy of the accomplished is called an evil mind.
Desiring to harm each other is called enmity.
Among those who do not yet know the Dharma, who are the practitioners' evil minds and enemies?

The sutra says:
The World-Honored One said:

Sin is the enemy of the evil mind.

This is the answer.
Answer the first four questions in order.
Merit is the retinue of good answers the first question.
Merit refers to the three virtues of giving, morality, and cultivation.
There are three kinds of giving.
First, material giving.
It is accomplished by the wholesome roots of non-greed.
Second, giving of fearlessness.
It is accomplished by the wholesome roots of non-hatred.
Third, giving of the Dharma.
It is accomplished by the wholesome roots of non-delusion.
There are three kinds of morality.
First, morality of restraining others.
It refers to the three bodily [actions].
It is accomplished by the wholesome roots of non-greed.
Second, morality of not harming others.
It refers to the four verbal [actions].
It is accomplished by the wholesome roots of non-hatred.
Third, morality of benefiting others.
It refers to the continuous arising of these two kinds of merit.
It is accomplished by the wholesome roots of non-delusion.
There are three kinds of cultivation.
First, the four meditations.
It is accomplished by the wholesome roots of non-greed.
Second, the four immeasurable [minds].
It is accomplished by the wholesome roots of non-hatred.
Third, the four formless [absorptions].
It is accomplished by the wholesome roots of non-delusion.
Moreover, among the six perfections, the first five are also merit.
Such merits and virtues all take the ten wholesome courses of action as their nature.
If one cultivates the two merits of giving and morality,
one will be reborn in the human or heavenly realms of the desire realm and attain a superior body.
Outwardly, one will attract pure retinues who observe the ten wholesome deeds.
This means that one's life will not be cut short,
one will be greatly wealthy and practice pure conduct,
one's words will be sincere and truthful,
one will always speak gently,
one's retinue will not be separated,
one will reconcile disputes well,
one's words will always be beneficial,
one will be free from jealousy and anger,
and one will have a retinue of those with right views.
If one cultivates the merit of meditation,
one will attain a superior body in the form and formless realms.
These three merits will ultimately lead to the attainment of the holy fruits of the three vehicles.
The meaning of the answer is as follows:
The retinue of worldly goodness will temporarily gather but will eventually part.
It is difficult to gather but easy to disperse.
It cannot be relied upon for a long time.
One does not yet know the three merits and wholesome actions within the Dharma that are true and firm.
It often benefits practitioners.
Among all relatives, this is the best.
As for sins are the enemy of evil thoughts, it answers the second question.
Destroying the Three Jewels, committing the five heinous crimes, and the ten evil deeds are all called sins.
Because of these sins,
They can cause sentient beings to revolve and fall into the three evil paths,
Suffering for a long eon.
The meaning of this answer is that evil thoughts in the world only harm one's own body,
And are still called enemies.
In the Dharma, sinful karma,
Can harm many bodies.

Therefore, it says sins are the enemy of evil thoughts.
As for the most severe suffering in hell, it answers the third question.

This is a blue lotus flower.ğŸ”½The petals of this flower are fine.

Seventh, padma.

Because the flesh is cracked widely, it resembles this flower blooming.

This is a white lotus flower.
Because the bones are cracked, it resembles this flower blooming.
The first two are named after the physical characteristics.
The next three are named after the sound characteristics.
The last three are named after the wound characteristics.
Moreover, the first two are clear cries.ğŸ”½The next three are unclear cries.
The last three are no cries.
These eight are between the four continents.
They are at the bottom of the Iron Ring Mountains.
They face upward and are located in the mind.
The sinners suffer from the pain of cold and freezing in it.
There are three kinds of neighboring hells:
One is between mountains,
two is between waters,
and three is in the wilderness.
One receives retribution for one's own karma.
One experiences cold and heat mixed.
The meaning of this answer is as follows:

Although there are sufferings such as killing, binding, imprisonment, encountering enemies, separation from loved ones, illness, and death in the human realm, as well as the sufferings of animals and hungry ghosts,
compared to the hells, they are not even one percent.
Even if one compares them to millions and trillions, they still do not reach even one.
Therefore, it is said that the hells are of extreme heavy suffering.
The answer to the fourth question is that the first bliss of non-arising is called non-arising.
Because of non-arising,
it is ultimately not extinguished.
The sages realize this,
and peacefully enter nirvana.
It is eternally abiding and peaceful.
Therefore, it is the ultimate bliss.
The meaning of this answer is as follows:
The ultimate bliss in the world ends in suffering.
How can it compare to nirvana, which is without suffering and eternally blissful?
Therefore, the sutra says:
What is high must fall.
That which is constant must come to an end.
That which is united must separate.
That which is pleasant must end in suffering.
This verse clarifies the false happiness of birth and death, that extreme happiness must end in suffering.
It also says:
All conditioned things are impermanent, subject to arising and ceasing.
When arising and ceasing cease,
cessation is bliss.
This verse clarifies the absence of suffering in nirvana.
It is ultimately constant bliss.
Therefore, it is called the supreme bliss of non-arising.

This is the initial request.

What is not suitable to be loved? What is suitable but not loved? This is the first and second question.
For example, sweet food mixed with poison, although loved,
harms the body and endangers life.
It should not be eaten.
Also, good medicine with a bitter taste is not loved,

It should be taken.

benefit practice.

In the unknown Dharma, which is loved by the mindğŸ”½but is not suitable for the body?
Which is suitable for the body
but is not loved by the mind?

Kama disease is called a hot disease in the world.

Good means virtuous.

Thoroughly understanding the nature of medicine,
Curing is certain.
Called a good doctor.

First, knowing the illness.

The sutra says:
The World-Honored One said:
Desires and love are not appropriate.
Explaining what is appropriate and not loved.
Greed is an extremely hot illness.
The Buddha is a great good doctor - Commentary:
This is the answer.
It sequentially answers the previous four questions.
Desires and love are not appropriate answers the first question.
Desires refers to the five desirable objects of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch.
They are called desires because they can give rise to desirous thoughts and are what is taken up.
The sutra says:
The five desires deceive people.
It is like a knife smeared with honey. One who licks it will be hurt by the blade.
It is like a cauterized scab. Although it brings slight pleasure at first,
it will later cause great pain.
It is like holding a torch against the wind. If one does not let go, one will certainly be burned.
It is like a king who became greedy for sex and lost his position.
A sage who loved sound fell from the sky into a forest.ğŸ”½A bhiká¹£u who smelled incense was scolded by the river god.
A Å›rÄmaá¹‡era who tasted flavors was thrown into a pond and became a dragon.
RÄma who was attached to touch lost his spiritual powers.
Moreover, these five desires are presently subject to three kinds of suffering.
That is to say, when seeking, one gives rise to the suffering of hard work.ğŸ”½When guarding, one gives rise to the suffering of fear.
When losing, one gives rise to the suffering of vexation.
Moreover, because of pursuing the five desires in an improper way,
one will again fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals and suffer for many days.
Later, one will be born among humans and gods, poor and suffering.
The suffering of being separated from what one loves.
The suffering of encountering what one hates.
Such sufferings are all due to the causes and conditions of being attached to the five desires.
Therefore, it is known that although the five desires are what ordinary people's minds love,
they are extremely unsuitable for practitioners.
Therefore, it is said that the desires and love are unsuitable.
Liberation is suitable, but not loved answers the second question.
Nirvana, being unconditioned, is free from all bonds.
Therefore, it is called liberation.
One who realizes liberation is forever free from birth and death.
Abiding eternally and peacefully,
in accordance with liberation, it is extremely suitable for practitioners.
But ordinary foolish people do not love it.
Therefore, it is said that liberation is suitable, but not loved.
Therefore, the sutra says:
Ordinary people would rather enjoy the body of a leprous fox
than enjoy nirvana.
A fox still has eyes, ears, and a mind,
but nirvana does not.
Greed is the most severe illness answers the third question.
Greed is the greed that binds.
Its essence pervades the three realms.
It universally obstructs the five questions.
It accompanies the six consciousnesses.
It equally defiles the six sense objects.
It is the foundation of the suffering and distress of birth and death.
How can the fever of the world compare to this?
As the Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom says:
The fire of desire blazes and burns the heavenly sacrifices.
Isn't craving and love the most extreme fever?
Even now, one is burned by fire.
In future lives, how can one avoid boiling in hot water?
Therefore, it is said that craving is the most extreme fever.
The Buddha is the great good doctor answers the fourth question.
The TathÄgata's five eyes
are illuminated internally with the six spiritual powers and externally.
Looking up, he observes the three periods of time.
Looking across, he sees the ten directions.
As for the source of physical and mental illness, he completely illuminates the methods of counteracting and curing, all as if they were before his eyes.
Therefore, the teachings he establishes accord with the capacities of sentient beings and all conform to their inherent natures.
He prescribes medicine according to the illness, and none do not benefit.
Thus, the Buddha is the greatest good doctor.
The Ä€gama Sutras say:
The Buddha has four knowledges:
First, he knows suffering;
Second, he knows the causes of suffering;
Third, he knows the cessation of suffering;
Fourth, he knows the path to the cessation of suffering.
Therefore, he is called the good doctor.
Moreover, the sutra says:
The medical treatments of worldly physicians,
Although cured, will recur.
The treatments of the TathÄgata, Once cured, will never recur.
Therefore, the Buddha is said to be the great physician.

One does not see forms and appearances.
I do not yet know what else in the Dharma obscures the world.
One does not recognize principles.
By whom is the world enchanted? This is the second question.
It is like ghosts and spirits in the world enchanting people and causing them to become foolish.

Causing it to be confused and disordered.
Who causes people to abandon their friends? This is the third question.
Friends and companions are intimate, so they become close friends.
If they become close because of wealth,
When the wealth is exhausted, they become distant.
If they become close because of power,
When the power is lost, they become obstructed.
This is like the case of Zhang Chen who became estranged at the end of the Xiao Zhu era.

Who again obstructs rebirth in the heavens? This is the fourth question.
The superior rewards of the heavens are all enjoyed by people.
By whom is it obstructed, so that one cannot be reborn there?
The sutra says:
The World-Honored One said: Ignorance covers the world.
The world is enchanted by delusion.
Stinginess and greed abandon close friends.

This is the answer.
It sequentially answers the previous four questions.
Ignorance covers the world answers the first question.
There is no knowledge of the four noble truths of suffering, origination, cessation, and the path.
Or there is no knowledge of the two truths of ultimate and conventional.
This is called ignorance.
Ignorance is precisely the affliction of ignorance.
Because of ignorance,
One does not know the fruits of suffering and the causes of origination in the cycle of birth and death.
One does not know the causes of the path of liberation and the fruits of cessation.
One does not know the one characteristic of ultimate truth, which is unconditioned.
One does not know the three periods of time and the causes and effects of conventional truth.
The meaning of this answer is as follows:
The blindness and darkness of the world only covers the physical eye.
The absence of wisdom covers the worldly wisdom eye.
Therefore, it is said that the world is covered by ignorance.
As for the world is enchanted by delusion, it answers the second question.
Delusion is another name for ignorance.
Because of being enchanted by delusion,
One sees permanence in impermanence.
One sees self in non-self.
One sees purity in impurity.
One sees happiness in suffering.
All thoughts and understanding are completely inverted.
Such inversions are all due to foolishness.
Therefore, it is said that the world is enchanted by delusion.
The answer to the third question is: Stinginess and greed abandon relatives and friends.ğŸ”½Stinginess is being miserly with one's own possessions.
Greed is wanting others' wealth.
As it is said in the Vinaya:
There was a bhiká¹£u practicing concentration by the side of a pond.

The bhiká¹£u had an evil thought and wanted him to leave.

The shining maá¹‡i jewel,

Because of this matter, the Buddha also spoke this verse:

Therefore, we know that stinginess and greed can abandon relatives and friends.
Moreover, because of greed, one only desires others' wealth.
Because of stinginess, one does not practice giving.
In the place where one is reborn, one is poor and lacking.
There is no father, no mother.
There is no wife, no children.
There are no good friends.
There are no close friends.
Therefore, it is said that stinginess and greed abandon close friends.
The Chengshi Lun speaks of five kinds of stinginess.
First, stinginess in giving.
Second, stinginess in the home.
Third, stinginess in the place.
Fourth, stinginess in praise.
Fifth, stinginess in the Dharma.
These five kinds of stinginess all abandon close friends.
Answering the fourth question, Attachment obstructs rebirth in the heavens.
Heavens refers to the twenty-eight heavens.
All require disgust with the lower realms in order to be reborn in the higher realms.
If one is attached to the lower realms,
One cannot be reborn in the higher realms.
If one is attached to the five desires of the human realm,
And indulges in them without trying to be disgusted with and detach from them,
One cannot be reborn in the six heavens of desire.
As explained in detail in the sutras.
The Buddha's younger brother Nanda was disgusted with SundarÄ« and delighted in the heavenly maidens.
Only then did he uphold the precepts and aspire to be reborn in the heavens.
If one is attached to the five desires of the six heavens,
One will not be able to be reborn in the form realm heavens above.
If one is attached to the rewards of the form realm heavens,
One will not be able to be reborn in the formless realm heavens above.
Therefore, it is said that attachment obstructs rebirth in the heavens.
Moreover, the sages of the three vehicles are called the pure heavens.
If one is attached to the contaminated rewards of the twenty-eight heavens in the three realms,
One will not be able to enter the holy path of the three vehicles.
This is also called attachment obstructing rebirth in the heavens.

Question:
Thieves act unreasonably, so one can resist them.

Answer:
Just as King Zhou of Yin was tyrannical and King Wu of Zhou resisted him.
Although he was the king's people,ğŸ”½he still resisted the king.

The minister then recorded the things he had cultivated for blessings.
The king became angry and said:

The minister replied to the king:

The king's mind opened up and he understood.

Therefore, it is known that those blessings cannot be taken away by others.
It is said:

Therefore, it is said that blessings can float and support the world.
Question:

What Confucius and Laozi say is that Heaven and Earth give birth to people, while what the Buddhist school clarifies is that people give birth to Heaven and Earth.
It is said that due to the power of the shared karma of sentient beings, the external environment of the world is formed. Heaven and Earth are the dependent environment.

All that is created in the three realms is one mind.
The treatise also says:
The external is accomplished by the internal.

They then said that Heaven and Earth give birth to people.
The Tathagata thoroughly knows the internal body and its causes and effects.
Therefore, he said that people give birth to Heaven and Earth.
The depths and shallows of the three teachings can be known from this.
